item.title: The local elections in Barnet: What really happened?
item.description: The Barnet council result has been the most startling in the recent local elections. Consistently predicted in pre-election polls as a Labour gain, Labour’s top target delivered an increased majority for the Conservatives. Many local people from all parties who were on the campaign trail have been quick to connect the Barnet result with Labour’s anti-semitism problems including Labour councillors and Barnet’s Labour leader. A blog by Dr Daniel Allington provides evidence for the link by showing a positive correlation between the increase in Conservative vote share in 2018 and the proportion of a ward that is Jewish and a similar decrease in the Labour vote, inferring that anti-semitism in Labour is likely to have driven the result in these key wards.

item.title: Why 'What is a Data Scientist?' is the wrong question to ask
item.description: In a recent interview on Dataframed podcast, Julia Silge, spoke of her background in Observational Astronomy and how applicable it was in Data Science. Later she gave a good explanation of her work in textual analytics and how it differs from Natural Language Processing, again as a method for observation rather than prediction. I found her use of wording interesting and thought it should have some credence in every data scientists’ favourite debate “What is a Data Scientist?

item.title: UK Election Data: Where to find open data and interesting metrics
item.description: Most electoral analysis is conducted by academics with University resources and collaborators. Not working in an academic institution and having spent some time researching what actually happened in the 2017 election, I have gathered some useful open data source and insights for election data that I thought would be helpful to share. In the following series of blog posts, I will describe where to find the data and why each bit of data is useful.

item.title: About
item.description: I have been working in Data Science since completing my PhD in Computer Science (Imperial College London, 2010). Details of my professional experience can be found on LinkedIn. I have experience applying Data Science and Analytics in areas including e-commerce, digital marketing and political research. My Data Science interests include the multi-touch marketing channel attribution problem, effective data communication and visualisation, survey design and interpretation, exploratory data analysis, textual analytics and working with R.

item.title: Contact
item.description: Contact me on Twitter, LinkedIn or email abigail dot lebrecht at gmail dot com

item.title: Home
item.description: Data Science Consultant interested in the effective communication of data, understanding uncertainty, visualisation and coding in R. Available for consultancy in London, UK or remote work.
